title: 113_hr5169
content: The "Senior Executive Service Accountability Act" requires biennial justification of positions with specific expected results and extends the probationary period from 1 to 2 years for senior executive service members. It also modifies pay retention for members removed for underperformance. Section 3594(c)(1)(B) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to ensure career appointees receive basic pay at the highest rate for their position, either at the time of placement or the rate before being appointed to the Senior Executive Service. Section 3594(c)(1)(B) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to ensure career appointees receive basic pay at the highest rate for their position. SEC. 5. Performance requirements must be established in advance, not later than 30 calendar days and communicated in writing. SEC. 6. Amendments to adverse action provisions for career appointees in the Senior Executive Service. (a) Suspension for 14 Days or Less for Senior Executive Service Employee.--Paragraph (1) of Section 7501 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to define an employee as an individual in the competitive service who is not on probation or has completed 1 year of continuous employment in a similar position, or a career appointee in the Senior Executive Service who has completed the probationary period. (b) Modification of Cause and Procedure for Suspension and Termination.--Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code is modified. Termination. Section 7543 of title 5, United States Code is amended to include provisions for extending deadlines for employee answers and agency decisions by up to 30 days each. An agency head must provide written documentation for any extensions granted. The amendment adds provisions for employees subject to removal to pay back received pay and lose accrued annual leave if a final order favors the agency. It applies to employees on administrative leave or similar status without duties but with pay. Conforming amendments are made to title 5, United States Code. The amendment modifies provisions related to employee removal by emphasizing the need for cause that promotes service efficiency, including misconduct. It also includes consequences such as repaying received pay and losing accrued annual leave if the agency's final order is in their favor. The House of Representatives passed the amendment on September 16, 2014. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
